content.title: SMA Embolism vs Thrombosis

definition.primary: Acute occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) can result from either embolism (sudden occlusion by dislodged material, typically cardiac) or in-situ thrombosis (acute occlusion superimposed on chronic atherosclerotic stenosis). Distinguishing between these mechanisms is critical as they differ in presentation, treatment approach, and prognosis.
key_concepts: Embolism accounts for ~50% of acute mesenteric ischemia cases
Thrombosis typically occurs in patients with known chronic mesenteric ischemia
Emboli lodge distal to vessel origins; thrombosis occurs at stenosis
Treatment approach differs significantly between the two

epidemiology.source: Cardiac in 90%+ (atrial fibrillation, recent MI, valve disease, cardiomyopathy)

presentation.pain: Severe abdominal pain out of proportion to physical findings
presentation.history: No prior postprandial pain or food fear
presentation.classic_triad: Atrial fibrillation, sudden severe abdominal pain, gut emptying (vomiting, diarrhea)

anatomic_location.typical: SMA distal to middle colic artery origin (3-8 cm from ostium)
anatomic_location.explanation: Emboli lodge at vessel bifurcations or areas of narrowing
anatomic_location.sparing: Proximal jejunum typically spared due to patent proximal branches

imaging_findings.cta: Filling defect distal to SMA origin, often 'meniscus sign'
imaging_findings.collaterals: Absent or minimal (no time to develop)

epidemiology.background: Chronic atherosclerotic stenosis with superimposed acute occlusion

presentation.pain: Severe but may have premonitory symptoms
presentation.history: Often history of postprandial pain, food fear, weight loss (chronic mesenteric ischemia)
presentation.context: May occur after dehydration, hypotension, or cardiac event

anatomic_location.typical: SMA ostium or within first 1-2 cm
anatomic_location.explanation: Thrombosis occurs at site of pre-existing atherosclerotic stenosis

imaging_findings.cta: Occlusion at SMA origin, calcified atherosclerotic plaque
imaging_findings.collaterals: Well-developed collaterals (developed during chronic stenosis phase)

imaging_differentiation.embolism: Distal to middle colic (3-8 cm from ostium)
SMA predominantly, may have splenic/renal emboli
imaging_differentiation.thrombosis: Often celiac and IMA also stenotic/occluded

endovascular.timing: May be considered if no bowel necrosis

surgical_approach.primary: Bypass grafting (retrograde from aorta or antegrade from iliac)
surgical_approach.rationale: Underlying severe stenosis requires reconstruction, not just embolectomy

endovascular.timing: After establishing patency, need to address underlying stenosis

adjuncts: Address other stenotic vessels if present

embolism.factors: Delay in diagnosis is primary determinant

thrombosis.factors: More extensive bowel involvement, older/sicker patients, multi-vessel disease

common_outcomes: Short bowel syndrome if extensive resection
Recurrence if source not addressed (anticoagulation for embolism, surveillance for thrombosis)

learning_objectives: Differentiate embolic from thrombotic SMA occlusion based on clinical history
Identify imaging features that distinguish embolism from thrombosis
Select appropriate surgical approach for each mechanism
Understand the prognostic differences between embolism and thrombosis
Apply secondary prevention strategies based on etiology
key_points: Embolism lodges 3-8 cm from ostium; thrombosis occurs at ostium
Prior postprandial symptoms suggest underlying stenosis and thrombosis
Atrial fibrillation is the most common embolic source
Embolectomy is appropriate for embolism; bypass required for thrombosis
Thrombosis carries higher mortality due to more extensive involvement
clinical_pearls: Look for collaterals on CTA - their presence suggests chronic stenosis
Embolism patients often have concurrent emboli (check kidneys, spleen)
Don't attempt embolectomy for ostial thrombosis - you need a bypass
Both require second-look laparotomy in 24-48 hours
